title: Estimate the marginal \(\sigma\)-significativity of \(c\) — marginal.significativity
text: function evaluates \(\sigma\)-significativity agreement value \(c\) \(\mathcal{M}_{(s,\cdot)}\). \(\mathcal{M}_{(s,\cdot)}\) set confusion matrices \(|s|\) rows columns elements \(\)-th row sum \(s()\). \(\sigma\)-significativity \(c\) \(\mathcal{M}_{(s,\cdot)}\) ratio number matrices \(M \\mathcal{M}_{(s,\cdot)}\) \(\sigma(M) < c\) cardinality \(\mathcal{M}_{(s,\cdot)}\). corresponds probability choosing uniform distribution matrix \(M \\mathcal{M}_{(s,\cdot)}\) \(\sigma(M) < c\).

title: Estimate the marginal \(\sigma\)-significativity of \(c\) — marginal.significativity
text: sigma agreement measure. c agreement value. s vector natural values. number_of_samples number samples used evaluate significativity using Monte Carlo method (default: 10000).

title: Estimate the marginal \(\sigma\)-significativity of \(c\) — marginal.significativity
text: function returns \(\sigma\)-significativity \(c\) \(\mathcal{M}_{(s,\cdot)}\) estimated Monte Carlo method using number_of_samples samples.

title: Estimate the marginal \(\sigma\)-significativity of \(c\) — marginal.significativity
code: # define a vector defining the number of classifications of a # two-class classifier  s <- as.integer(c(10, 1))  # gauge kappa-significativity of 0.5 in M_{(s,.)} with 10000 samples marginal.significativity(cohen_kappa, 0.5, s) #> [1] 0.9032  # define a different vector defining the number of classifications of a # two-class classifier  s2 <- as.integer(c(6, 5))  # define a vector defining the number of classifications of a five-class # classifier  s3 <- as.integer(c(6, 5, 3, 8, 5))  # gauge kappa-significativity of 0.5 in M_{(s3,.)} with 10000 samples marginal.significativity(cohen_kappa, 0.5, s3) #> [1] 0.9995  # gauge kappa-significativity of 0.5 in M_{(s3,.)} with 40000 samples marginal.significativity(cohen_kappa, 0.5, s3, number_of_samples=40000) #> [1] 0.99955  # gauge kappa-significativity of 0.5 in M_{(s2,.)} with 10000 samples marginal.significativity(cohen_kappa, 0.5, s2) #> [1] 0.8552  # define a (2x2)-confusion matrix M <- matrix(as.integer(c(9, 0, 1, 1)), nrow=2) M #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    9    1 #> [2,]    0    1 cohen_kappa(M) #> [1] 0.6206897  # gauge kappa-significativity of cohen_kappa(M) in M_{(rowSums(M),.)} # with 10000 samples marginal.significativity(cohen_kappa, cohen_kappa(M),                          as.integer(rowSums(M))) #> [1] 0.914  # define another (2x2)-confusion matrix M2 <- matrix(as.integer(c(5, 0, 1, 5)), nrow=2) M2 #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    5    1 #> [2,]    0    5 cohen_kappa(M2) #> [1] 0.8196721  # gauge kappa-significativity of cohen_kappa(M2) in M_{(rowSums(M2),.)} # with 10000 samples marginal.significativity(cohen_kappa, cohen_kappa(M2),                          as.integer(rowSums(M2))) #> [1] 0.9548

title: Uniformly sampling \(\Delta^{(k-1)}\) — sample_prob_simplex
text: function samples k-dimensional probability simplex \(\Delta^{(k-1)}=\left\{ \langle x_1, \ldots x_k \rangle \\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}^k\, |\, \sum_{=1}^k x_i = 1\right\}\) using uniform probability distribution.

title: Uniformly sampling \(\Delta^{(k-1)}\) — sample_prob_simplex
text: k dimension probability simplex sampled.

title: Uniformly sampling \(\Delta^{(k-1)}\) — sample_prob_simplex
text: sample \(\Delta^{(k-1)}\) taken according uniform probability distribution.

title: Uniformly sampling \(\Delta^{(k-1)}\) — sample_prob_simplex
code: # sample the 5-dimensional probability simplex sample_prob_simplex(5) #> [1] 0.1701992 0.1082816 0.2597004 0.2710165 0.1908022  # successive calls may produce different results sample_prob_simplex(5) #> [1] 0.01736597 0.16952667 0.43687385 0.18650819 0.18972533  # setting the random seed before the call guarantee repeatability set.seed(1) sample_prob_simplex(5) #> [1] 0.05830519 0.15783181 0.55531351 0.01952378 0.20902571  set.seed(1) sample_prob_simplex(5) #> [1] 0.05830519 0.15783181 0.55531351 0.01952378 0.20902571

title: The \(\sigma\)-significativity of \(c\) — significativity
text: function evaluates \(\sigma\)-significativity agreement value \(c\) either \(\mathcal{M}_{n,m}\) \(\mathcal{P}_{n}\) depending call parameters. m natural number, \(\sigma\)-significativity \(c\) \(\mathcal{M}_{n,m}\) evaluated. number_of_samples natural number, significativity estimated using Monte Carlo method. Otherwise, computation considers \(n \times n\)-confusion matrices. instead m set NULL, function uses Monte Carlo method estimate \(\sigma\)-significativity \(c\) \(\mathcal{P}_{n}\).

title: The \(\sigma\)-significativity of \(c\) — significativity
text: sigma agreement measure. c agreement value. n number rows/columns confusion matrix. m sum confusion matrix elements. set NULL, function estimate \(\sigma\)-significativity \(c\) \(\mathcal{P}_{n}\) (default: NULL). number_of_samples number samples used evaluate significativity using Monte Carlo method (default: 10000).

title: The \(\sigma\)-significativity of \(c\) — significativity
text: m natural number, function returns \(\sigma\)-significativity \(c\) \(\mathcal{M}_{n,m}\). instead m set NULL, \(\sigma\)-significativity \(c\) \(\mathcal{P}_{n}\).

title: The \(\sigma\)-significativity of \(c\) — significativity
code: # evaluate kappa-significativity of 0.5 in M_{2,5} with 10000 samples significativity(cohen_kappa, 0.5, 2, 5) #> [1] 0.8263  # evaluate kappa-significativity of 0.5 in M_{2,5} with 1000 samples significativity(cohen_kappa, 0.5, 2, 5, number_of_samples = 1000) #> [1] 0.804  # exactly compute kappa-significativity of 0.5 in M_{2,5} significativity(cohen_kappa, 0.5, 2, 5, number_of_samples = NULL) #> [1] 0.8214286  # evaluate kappa-significativity of 0.5 in P_{2} with 1000 samples significativity(cohen_kappa, 0.5, 2, number_of_samples = 1000) #> [1] 0.886  # evaluate kappa-significativity of 0.5 in P_{2} with 10000 samples significativity(cohen_kappa, 0.5, 2) #> [1] 0.897  # successive calls to Monte Carlo methods may produce different results significativity(cohen_kappa, 0.5, 2) #> [1] 0.8982  # setting the random seed before the call guarantee repeatability set.seed(1) significativity(cohen_kappa, 0.5, 2) #> [1] 0.9012  set.seed(1) significativity(cohen_kappa, 0.5, 2) #> [1] 0.9012

title: The lexicographic weak composition enumeration — weak_composition_enum
text: function implements lexicographic order enumerator weak compositions \(m\) \(k\) parts. weak composition \(m\) \(k\) parts vector \(k\) natural numbers whose sum \(m\). \(\mathcal{C}_{m,k}\) set weak composition \(m\) \(k\) parts. lexicographic order \(<_l\) \(\mathcal{C}_{m,k}\) order weak compositions \(m\) \(k\) parts \(\langle a_1,\ldots a_k \rangle <_l \langle b_1,\ldots b_k \rangle\) exist \(\[1, k]\) \(j \[1, -1]\) holds \(a_j = b_j\) \(a_i<b_i\).

title: The lexicographic weak composition enumeration — weak_composition_enum
text: m sum natural values output vector. k size output vector. index index output vector lexicographic order.

title: The lexicographic weak composition enumeration — weak_composition_enum
text: index-th weak composition lexicographic order \(\mathcal{C}_{m,k}\).

title: The lexicographic weak composition enumeration — weak_composition_enum
code: # evaluate the 1st element in the lexicographic order of C_{100, 5} weak_composition_enum(100, 5, 0) #> [1]   0   0   0   0 100  # evaluate it again weak_composition_enum(100, 5, 0) #> [1]   0   0   0   0 100  # evaluate the 42137th element in the lexicographic order of C_{100, 5} weak_composition_enum(100, 5, 42137) #> [1]  0  8 56 33  3
